head.title: Prologue to an Oglio.1, 1First published in Poems (1794), pp. 34-36.22 Variant of olio; a musical medley.

lg.l: Let others tell of Greece and ancient Rome,
Where learning sleeps beneath the mould’ring tomb;
Or wander in the fam’d aonian33 Poetic term relating to Boeotia, especially Mt. Helicon, home of the Muses. shades,
To hear the harps of the Harmonious Maids:—

Those seats, so favour’d by the Nine of yore,44 The nine Muses. Cf. Thomas Warton: “To hold short dalliance with the tuneful Nine” (Warton, Triumph of Isis ([749], lines 97-98); and Robert Burns: “there are such who court the tuneful nine—,” "To Robert Graham of Fintry, Esqr, with a Request for an Excise Division," line 75 (sent to Graham September 10, 1788, first published in Currie, 1800; Kinsley, I: 427; III: 1279).
Can boast their sacred influence no more:
No chearful numbers glad, or hill, or plain,
Where Tyranny and dire oppression reign.
But, bless’d Britannia! thine’s the favour’d seat,
To which the tuneful sisters all retreat.
They lov’d thy clime, they lov’d thy happy ground,
And on thy plains a safe asylum found;
Where heav’n-born Liberty’s auspicious smile
Makes arts to flourish through the far fam’d Isle!
Not to the cells where hoary seers retire,
Nor where the academic tow’rs aspire,
Not only to the opulent and gay
Doth Science her unbounded stores display:
But like a garden, to its utmost bound,
Fair flow’rs of learning ev’ry where are found.
What tongue can speak, or pen can e’er describe
The matchless merits of thy tuneful tribe!
Where genius, with politest arts combin’d,
Soften, delight, and elevate the mind.
Such universal lessons they afford,
The humble peasant emulates his lord;
Such boundless knowledge through Britannia reigns,
A philosophic school each lowly roof contains.
Since such the character of British wit,
A British audience sure is fully fit
The works of genius justly to approve,
To feel where satire stings, or the soft passions move.
Permit us then, those beauties to explore,
And cull from out the unexausted store,
Such precious relicts of each gentle muse,
As candour, sense, and elegance would chuse;
And, with submission to superior taste,
Offer a sweet poetical repast.
